title: See Riot, people loved that Ekko comic. Why can't you do something like that weekly/bi-weekly?
body: Lore fans would be so much happier seeing something like that every week or every other week.

replies.body: Because making comics weekly wouldn't give them any money

You would be amazed at how many times I speak about money when it comes to the deciding factor in making creative decisions. By that I mean I can't remember ever doing that.

My role is one that supports Narrative in particular, and then the teams that we work within. I have never been in a room talking about whether to make something from a story standpoint, including format or cadence, based on how much money it will make Riot.

Ever.

It's one of the many things I love about my extremely privileged position in working at Riot. You might not believe me, as if you would have told me that before I joined I might not have believed it either. Right or wrong, we make what we think players will love. Not what will sell the most. 

It's who we are. Seriously.

After nine months, I've stopped looking forward to that.

Not in the vein of Riot Hate that I see way too much of, just a mildly concerned/interested question here.

How long does it take to make one of these bios for champions? It has been a very long time, and I'm wondering if most of it was just trying to decide what exactly to do about champions, or if maybe some procrastination was involved. I only ask because I myself would love to be apart of the narrative team of League of Legends, (In fact it's sort of a dream job of mine) and it doesn't seem like it would take too long to decide what to do about certain champion's stories.

First of all, thanks for posting on the boards it is nice to hear from you!

I really liked the Ekko Comic, but I am fearful that all lore we are going to receive is just going to be with champion releases. I would really like to hear more about how the said champions interact outside of the rift (since SR isn't cannon). It would be really amazing if we could get something like dawngate had in their lore, it really made the world and game come alive so that it wasn't just about the "on-rift" actions.

Once again thanks for posting and I look forward to the long lore.

"Seriously guys, we have so much super awesome stuff, you'll get to see it Soonâ„¢, just trust us, ignore the years of empty promises and zero results, those don't count, because the stuff we have now is gonna knock your socks of! Come on, would we mislead you?"

But people really get the impression that narrative is some sort of money-grab advertising thing when the only time they come across some sort of lore EVER is to hype up a champion release, I think the only instance of lore we've got in the last year that's not directly hyping up a new champion release is that Amumu video.

So people end up thinking "Huh, the narrative team is only ever there to sell us a new champion, the reason we're not getting periodical wordlbuilding is because it doesn't represent sales".

I'm not saying new champions shouldn't get chunky lore events/videos/comics, I love that stuff and it'd be sad if you released a champion with a Rammus-like lore (Who knows what this thing is?, I have no idea, neither how he interacts with the world, nope) but there's a huge roster that needs a bit of worldbuilding of its own, specially now that most of them have been left in the air by the retcon thing.

The most important thing, the one thing where we're lacking the most, the thing that people are really hungry for is:

-Develop the relationships and interactions between the existing champions and the role they actively play in the world.

You may never need to talk about money in your position, it isn't your job and would be silly if you had to.....  But you know it is a factor.  You know any project you propose has to be signed off by someone who does the math and calculates 'is it worth it'.  I'm not saying Riot is greedy, but they are a business so please don't act otherwise.

Creating a continual comic would be expensive with little payout.  The fans would love it but Riot's accounting department wouldn't.

Many projects companies do don't have a direct profit, but do have an indirect one. LCS for example is wonderful advertising for Riot, even though they lose money on it at first. They make money in the long term. Publishing a comic may not make money itself, but the attention and excitement would generate good will and profits from lore fans through them staying around to play and purchase.

I will say it again.  The Project is proposed to someone who signs it off who is paid to ask, "Is it worth it?" 

So yes, attention and excitement can generate revenue.  People who get excited for a champion tend to buy them and their skin, making Riot cash.... But I believe you missed the point.  

EVERYTHING boils down to 'will it make money?' Acting like Riot is making this product for children's laughter and rainbows is to the least a half lie.
You are the exact opposite of ROBLOX, that's a good thing.

Being a regular on the Gameplay and Balance forum/board, I've had my view of Riot evolve more and more in favor of seeing Riot as a selfish company like every other. When I see post like this from Riot employees my faith is rekindled a bit. 

I'm reminded that in other games you rarely hear ANYTHING from ANYONE, outside of forum mods. Many companies take months, sometimes years to release new content which they do not even bother asking the playerbase how they feel about the changes. Riot on the otherhand does ask the playerbase what we like and tries to incorporate it into the game (so many Champions with jokes based off the playerbase). I think if more of us had reminders of how much Riot actually cares about their product vs competitors we may be a bit more forgiving regarding issues of Lore/Balance/Updates considering we get quite a fair amount of each (less so for the former, but still more than some).

To be fair, the LCS doesn't really make Riot money either. Maybe it will one day, but it's a money sink at the moment.

They still run and maintain the whole thing though.
I would guess that comic took more than two weeks to make, though, so a bi-weekly comic probably wouldn't be as large/detailed/thought through as Ekko's was.
Indeed it did take longer, and we want every comic we consider making to be as high quality as Chronobreak.
Why not a monthly comic? Bi-monthly if need be? Obviously champion releases should be high quality, but some world-building is tolerable with lower colors and pictures.

It was okay. Too anime-ish for my tastes in that it's more focused on exaggerated feelings rather than any kind of actual coherency, so it feels too unreal and disconnected to have any kind of relationship with the characters.  They don't feel human or humane.

Now if the story quality could not be... quite that, the visuals are all right, the flow of the panel-by-panel comic style is very nice, and the plot itself is okay.  Work on the finer details and I would absolutely get behind this.  Thumbs up, clap clap, kudos and what-not.

A weekly comic like that would be incredibly expensive, not to mention have to be planned weeks in advance to give the artists time to work.

At one point I followed a web comic that did ONE page a week, with a line artist and a colorist. Eventually they dropped their workload to every two weeks. Then once a month.
And finally they dropped the comic altogether because it became too much for them to handle. 

As an artist myself, I don't want to take on the workload of a ten-page comic each week or even every other week.

Most of those webcomic are free time projects. On the other hand there are professional web comics that do five full high quality pages a week, with two or three people.

Sure the whole 11 page comic takes more than two weeks to make, but it goes through several stages, that individually are a lot shorter. And when you have different people handling the different stages, the next comic enter stage one as soon as the former gets to stage two.

There is usually: concept, writing, line art, inking, colouring, shading, lettering.

With the right setup and routine a small team could pour out a weekly comic like chronobreak.

It wouldn't even be that expensive, maybe 10.000 $ per issue or let it even be 20.000$ if they sell them really well. Heck if need be they could start selling the issues for as little as 50 RP each and make a huge profit.
